io.github.utk003.util.data.collection.slice

Interface Slice<E>

  • Type Parameters:
    E - The class type of the elements of this Slice
    All Superinterfaces:
    Iterable<E>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractSlice

    public interface Slice<E>
extends Iterable<E>
    An array-like object inspired by slices in Go.

    Slices are simply views of an underlying array, and they can be extended, shortened, or even sliced further to reduce the visible portion of the array. Like in Go, a slice has both a size, which refers to the length of the subarray to which the slice can write, and a capacity, which refers to the size of the slice and how much further the underlying array continues beyond the end of the slice's subarray.

    All slices created on an array and all slices formed by slicing, extending, or shortening an existing slice will be bound to the same underlying array. In other words, changes to the array, either directly or via a mutable slice, will be reflected in all such slices. To check whether a slice is backed by a specific array (or any object), the sharesBacking(Object) method can be used.

    To create a Slice object, use either wrap(Object[]) or wrap(Object[], int, int).

    Unmodifiable slices, created either using the makeUnmodifiable() instance method or the makeUnmodifiable(Object[]) static method(s), can be used to create immutable arrays.

    Although primarily designed for use with arrays, custom slice implementations can be created for other data structures. In such a case, the sharesBacking(Object) method should be used to verify whether an specific object backs the given slice.

    Since:
    2.1.0
    Version:
    June 11, 2021
    Author:
    Utkarsh Priyam (utk003)
    See Also:
    sharesBacking(Object), wrap(Object[]), wrap(Object[], int, int), makeUnmodifiable(), makeUnmodifiable(Object[]), makeUnmodifiable(Object[], int, int), makeUnmodifiable(Slice), Go

    • Method Detail

      • size

        int size()
        Returns the length of the subarray this slice can directly modify.

        This method is simply an alias for length().

        Returns:
        The length of this slice
        See Also:
        length()

      • length

        int length()
        Returns the length of the subarray this slice can directly modify.
        Returns:
        The length of this slice
        See Also:
        size()

      • capacity

        int capacity()
        Returns the capacity of the array underlying this slice.

        The capacity of this slice (or equivalently its underlying array) represents the maximum length of a subarray that any slice extending this slice can modify. This length is calculated as 

         array.length - slice.start_index
        where array.length is the total length of this slice's underlying array and slice.start_index is the starting index of this slice relative to that array.
        Returns:
        This slice's capacity (for extension)
        See Also:
        extend(int)

      • get

        E get(int ind)
        Returns the element in this slice at the given index.

        Indexing is calculated relative to the slice, not the underlying array. For example, if a slice starts at index 2 in an array, then accessing the element at index 0 (with respect to the slice) will return the element at index 2 in the array.

        Parameters:
        ind - The index of the element to retrieve, relative to the slice
        Returns:
        The retrieved element, if it exists
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index is less than 0 or greater than equal to length()

      • set

        void set(int ind,
         E obj)
        Sets the element in this slice at the given index to the specified value.

        Indexing is calculated relative to the slice, not the underlying array. For example, if a slice starts at index 2 in an array, then accessing the element at index 0 (with respect to the slice) will return the element at index 2 in the array.

        Parameters:
        ind - The index of the element to set, relative to the slice
        obj - The new value of the element
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index is less than 0 or greater than equal to length()

      • replace

        @NotNull
@NotNull Slice<E> replace(int ind,
                                   E obj)
        Replaces the element at the specified index with the new element value.

        This method is identical to set(int, Object), with one exception. This method returns this Slice object, so that other method calls on the same object can be chained one after another.

        Parameters:
        ind - The index of the element to set, relative to the slice
        obj - The new value of the element
        Returns:
        This Slice object
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index is less than 0 or greater than equal to length()
        See Also:
        set(int, Object)

      • apply

        @NotNull
@NotNull Slice<E> apply(int ind,
                                 @NotNull
                                 @NotNull Slice.Transformation<E> transformation)
        Applies the specified Transformation to the element at the specified index.

        This method returns this Slice object, so that other method calls on the same object can be chained one after another.

        Parameters:
        ind - The index of the element to change, relative to the slice
        transformation - The Transformation to apply to the element
        Returns:
        This Slice object
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index is less than 0 or greater than equal to length()
        See Also:
        replace(int, Object), Transformation

        @NotNull
@NotNull Slice<E> applyAll(@NotNull
                                    @NotNull Slice.Transformation<E> transformation)
        Applies the specified Transformation to all elements in the slice.

        This method returns this Slice object, so that other method calls on the same object can be chained one after another.

        Parameters:
        transformation - The Transformation to apply
        Returns:
        This Slice object
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the index is less than 0 or greater than equal to length()
        See Also:
        apply(int, Transformation), Transformation

      • trimStart

        @NotNull
@NotNull Slice<E> trimStart(int start)
        Creates a new (shorter) Slice object backed by the same array as this slice.

        This method is nearly identical in function to String.substring(int), except that the resulting Slice will reflect changes made by this Slice object or any other Slice object bound to the same array.

        This method is identical to calling trim(int, int) with the arguments (start, length()).

        Parameters:
        start - The starting index of the trimming operation, relative to this Slice object
        Returns:
        An new Slice object of the specified dimension
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the start index is less than 0 or greater than equal to length()
        See Also:
        trim(int, int), String.substring(int)

      • trimEnd

        @NotNull
@NotNull Slice<E> trimEnd(int end)
        Creates a new (shorter) Slice object backed by the same array as this slice.

        This method is similar to trimStart(int), except that the specified index is at the end of this Slice, not the start. Regardless, the resulting Slice will reflect changes made by this Slice object or any other Slice object bound to the same array.

        This method is identical to calling trim(int, int) with the arguments (0, end).

        Parameters:
        end - The ending index of the trimming operation, relative to this Slice object
        Returns:
        An new Slice object of the specified dimension
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the end index is less than 0 or greater than equal to length()
        See Also:
        trimStart(int), trim(int, int)

      • trim

        @NotNull
@NotNull Slice<E> trim(int start,
                                int end)
        Creates a new (shorter) Slice object backed by the same array as this slice.

        This method is nearly identical in function to String.substring(int, int), except that the resulting Slice will reflect changes made by this Slice object or any other Slice object bound to the same array.

        Simpler versions of this method exist, where the either the start or end index is taken to be the edge of this slice: trimStart(int) and trimEnd(int).

        Parameters:
        start - The starting index of the trimming operation, relative to this Slice object
        end - The ending index of the trimming operation, relative to this Slice object
        Returns:
        An new Slice object of the specified dimension
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If either index is less than 0 or greater than equal to length(), or if the resulting slice length is negative
        See Also:
        trimStart(int), trimEnd(int)

      • shorten

        @NotNull
@NotNull Slice<E> shorten(int by)
        Creates a new shorter Slice object backed by the same array as this slice.

        This method is identical to calling trim(int, int) with the arguments (0, size() - by).

        This same operation, applied to the front of this slice instead of the end, can be achieved by calling trimStart(int) with the argument (by).

        For a similar operation, extending the slice instead of shortening it, use extend(int).

        Parameters:
        by - The number of elements to remove off the end of this Slice
        Returns:
        An new Slice object of the specified dimension
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the resulting slice length is negative
        See Also:
        trimStart(int), trim(int, int), extend(int)

      • extend

        @NotNull
@NotNull Slice<E> extend(int by)
        Creates a new longer Slice object backed by the same array as this slice.

        This method extends the region of the underlying array that the slice can modify. In other words, 

             new_slice.length() == old_slice.length() + by
        must be true. If this is not possible (due to constraints from capacity()), then this method must throw a SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException

        The functionality provided by this method (extending a slice) cannot be achieved by any of the other slice-creation methods, as they all throw SliceIndexOutOfBoundsExceptions in such scenarios.

        For a similar operation (shortening the slice instead of extending it) use shorten(int).

        Parameters:
        by - The number of additional elements to append to the end of this Slice
        Returns:
        An new Slice object of the specified dimension
        Throws:
        SliceIndexOutOfBoundsException - If the underlying array does not have sufficient space to accommodate the extension
        See Also:
        shorten(int), capacity()

      • sharesBacking

        boolean sharesBacking(@NotNull
                      @NotNull Object arr)
        Checks whether the given Object is the object backing this Slice.

        This method should simply use == to check whether the given object equals the object used to back this Slice.

        In most cases, this backing object will be an array, but the argument type is Object to allow for custom implementations of Slice backed by other data structures.

        Parameters:
        arr - The object (typically an array) to check as a potential backer
        Returns:
        true if the given object backs this Slice; otherwise, false

      • wrap

        @NotNull
static <E> @NotNull Slice<E> wrap(@NotNull
                                           E[] arr)
        Creates a new Slice object backed by the given array.

        This method is identical to calling 

         wrap(arr, 0, arr.length).
        Type Parameters:
        E - The class type of the elements in the slice
        Parameters:
        arr - The array to wrap in a Slice object
        Returns:
        The new Slice object
        See Also:
        wrap(Object[], int, int)

      • wrap

        @NotNull
static <E> @NotNull Slice<E> wrap(@NotNull
                                           E[] arr,
                                           int from,
                                           int to)
        Creates a new Slice object backed by the given array.

        This method limits the part of the array the returned slice can modify correspond to the indices in the interval [from,to). For a slice-creation method that wraps the entire array, use wrap(Object[]) instead.

        Type Parameters:
        E - The class type of the elements in the slice
        Parameters:
        arr - The array to wrap in a Slice object
        from - The starting index of the slice, relative to the array
        to - The ending index of the slice, relative to the array
        Returns:
        The new Slice object
        See Also:
        wrap(Object[])

      • makeUnmodifiable

        @NotNull
@NotNull Slice<E> makeUnmodifiable()
        Returns an unmodifiable version of this Slice object.

        This method is identical to calling makeUnmodifiable(Slice) with the argument (this).

        Note that method will not make this slice's elements unmodifiable. This is especially an issue for multi-dimensional slices. Once the outermost slice is unmodifiable, the inner slices can no longer become unmodifiable (except via external modification to the underlying array), as making slices (or other collections) unmodifiable creates a new object instance that must then replace the original element in the slice. Therefore, to properly make such nested slices unmodifiable, the slices must be converted in reverse: starting with the innermost slices and working outwards. One simple way to achieve this is using the applyAll(Transformation) method: for a 3D slice (ie Slice<Slice<Slice<E>>> slice), either 

         slice.applyAll((slice2D) -> {
     return slice2D.applyAll((slice1D) -> {
         return slice1D.makeUnmodifiable();
     }).makeUnmodifiable();
 }).makeUnmodifiable();
        or (equivalently) 
         slice.applyAll((slice2D) -> slice2D.applyAll((slice1D) -> slice1D.makeUnmodifiable()).makeUnmodifiable()).makeUnmodifiable();
        would return a perfectly unmodifiable 3D slice.
        Returns:
        An unmodifiable version of this slice
        See Also:
        makeUnmodifiable(Slice), applyAll(Transformation)

      • makeUnmodifiable

        @NotNull
static <E> @NotNull Slice<E> makeUnmodifiable(@NotNull
                                                       E[] arr)
        Returns an unmodifiable Slice object backed by the given array.

        This method is an optimized way of performing wrap(Object[]) followed by either makeUnmodifiable() or makeUnmodifiable(Slice).

        This method is identical to calling 

         makeUnmodifiable(arr, 0, arr.length).
        Type Parameters:
        E - The class type of the elements in the slice
        Parameters:
        arr - The array to wrap in an unmodifiable Slice object
        Returns:
        The new unmodifiable Slice object
        See Also:
        wrap(Object[]), makeUnmodifiable(Slice), makeUnmodifiable(Object[], int, int)

      • makeUnmodifiable

        @NotNull
static <E> @NotNull Slice<E> makeUnmodifiable(@NotNull
                                                       E[] arr,
                                                       int from,
                                                       int to)
        Returns an unmodifiable Slice object backed by the given array.

        This method is an optimized way of performing wrap(Object[], int, int) followed by either makeUnmodifiable() or makeUnmodifiable(Slice).

        Like with the wrap(Object[], int, int) method, this method quite like makeUnmodifiable(Object[]), except that it provides an option to limit the region of the array corresponding to the returned Slice object. The part of the array the returned slice can modify correspond to the indices in the interval [from,to).

        Type Parameters:
        E - The class type of the elements in the slice
        Parameters:
        arr - The array to wrap in an unmodifiable Slice object
        from - The starting index of the slice, relative to the array
        to - The ending index of the slice, relative to the array
        Returns:
        The new unmodifiable Slice object
        See Also:
        wrap(Object[]), makeUnmodifiable(Slice), makeUnmodifiable(Object[], int, int)

      • makeUnmodifiable

        @NotNull
static <E> @NotNull Slice<E> makeUnmodifiable(@NotNull
                                                       @NotNull Slice<E> slice)
        Returns an unmodifiable version of the given Slice.

        This is simply a static version of makeUnmodifiable().

        Note that method will not make this slice's elements unmodifiable. This is especially an issue for multi-dimensional slices. Once the outermost slice is unmodifiable, the inner slices can no longer become unmodifiable (except via external modification to the underlying array), as making slices (or other collections) unmodifiable creates a new object instance that must then replace the original element in the slice. Therefore, to properly make such nested slices unmodifiable, the slices must be converted in reverse: starting with the innermost slices and working outwards. One simple way to achieve this is using the applyAll(Transformation) method: for a 3D slice (ie Slice<Slice<Slice<E>>> slice), either 

         slice.applyAll((slice2D) -> {
     return slice2D.applyAll((slice1D) -> {
         return slice1D.makeUnmodifiable();
     }).makeUnmodifiable();
 }).makeUnmodifiable();
        or (equivalently) 
         slice.applyAll((slice2D) -> slice2D.applyAll((slice1D) -> slice1D.makeUnmodifiable()).makeUnmodifiable()).makeUnmodifiable();
        would return a perfectly unmodifiable 3D slice.
        Type Parameters:
        E - The class type of the elements in the slice
        Parameters:
        slice - The slice to make unmodifiable
        Returns:
        The new unmodifiable Slice object
        See Also:
        makeUnmodifiable(), applyAll(Transformation)
